This is the best addon and best Half-Life game among official Goldsource releases on PC
It's not as rough and unpolished as Half-Life 1 and it's not as messy and chaotic as Op4
It blends detailed maps with the actual storyline, which evolves as the plot moves on
Opposing Force story was kinda silly, inexplicably transiting from "save your ass" to "save the goddamn world". Well, at least, protagonist wasn't nerdy scientist like in Half-Life 1.
Blue Shift is the the only HL game, that allows you to play as the real character, even if he is still keeping silence all the time and, in fact, represents flying hands, holding a weapons. How's that? Pretty easy - the story is not about "save planet" bullshit anymore, it's about personal safety and it shows us fate of a simple people rather than killing machines. Barney Calhoun is just a security guard and all that he want to is to get alive from this nightmare. That brings global conflict with alien invasion and cruel marines on a more personal level. 
Here Gearbox went even further and made a real plot-driving character, years before Valve and its Half-Life 2. Rosenberg became natural evolution of fat and funny security guard Otis, who was a statist, yeah, but at same time he was charismatic and memorable. Dialogues now are longer and more infromative yet they are still "you need to do this..."-like. You can finally feel the tension between HECU and Black Mesa personal and dead bodies of your colleagues become something more than just part of the map. It's awesome how from classic HL1 ingridients you can build much more smart and interesting game. 
While in Half-Life 1 maps often were just poorly-designed, Blue Shift makes a bet on small, but detailed locations. There are not many areas under the open sky, but their quality is way higher than quality of the most open HL1 maps put together. Good lighting and amount of unnecessary, but cool feauters create immersive Black Mesa experience. And you should see Xen there! The best portrayal of the border world in series. Maps often look like a circle, so in the end you can find a way to the beginning - another nice thing that shows how thought out maps are.
Gameplay... Well, i've completed this game entirely without getting any damage. Can only say, that there are a lot of action packed in a small amount time needed to finish this addon, and this action is pleasant.
In conclusion, Blue Shift is the most polished and well-made game of all Half-Life games on Gldsrc engine. I recommend you to play it.

Blue shift is the Half-life game I've read more negative reviews about than any other official Half-life game. But to be honest, I think it's not that bad. Sure, it doesn't feature anything very new (compared to opposing force), but it's still enjoyable. Though the "tunnel" part in Xen reminds me heavily of the vent-labyrinth in the main Half-life, and is just as annoying. I've heard some people complain about the section where you escort Dr.Rosenberg, but I don't think it's that bad. It's pretty short after all. I also like all the moments where you can spot Gordon Freeman along his adventure as well. To conclude, I feel this game get's a lot more hate than it deserves. Sure, it doesn't bring much new to the table, but that's about it.
If you liked the original Half-life, you will most likely like this one as well!

An underrated gem in the Half-Life series. While I feel like Opposing Force is overrated and easily my least favorite official HL game, Blue Shift is probably my favorite HL1 expansion. It’s short, and doesn’t add any new enemies or weapons like OpFor does. It doesn’t even use the complete roster of weapons and enemies that HL uses. Honestly, I think that’s to it’s benefit. It doesn’t have as many annoying enemies from HL, such as the Black Ops assassins, or the Alien Controllers, aside from one instance, and it doesn’t have some of the more redundant weapons from HL, such as the Hivehand or the Tripmines, though I believe you can obtain Tripmines in the game. 

The storytelling is a bit more like HL2 in a way where you more directly interact with actual named characters, such as Dr. Rosenberg, instead of the mostly samey looking scientists and security guards in HL. It also has segments that are more like interactive cutscenes where other characters move around doing things while talking to you. This can be seen as either good or bad depending on how much you like that in HL2. 

Also, this game, unlike OpFor, just feels more like a Half-Life game. What do I mean by that? Well I mean that it actually fleshes out more aspects of the original game’s story as opposed to being a self contained story set loosely around the events of the original game that also happens to take place in the same setting. It also serves as a story that explains how Barney managed to escape Black Mesa and meet up with you during HL2. Neat, huh?

(Also, it doesn’t lazily recycle certain areas from the original game like OpFor, and instead lets you explore other parts of the Black Mesa Facility that Gordon never got to visit in HL).

Sorry to those who like Opposing Force, but I just don’t enjoy it as much as I did Blue Shift. I agree that it’s too short and doesn’t add much in the way of new content, but it’s just better designed and more fun to play. I’d make a review about Opposing Force instead of bringing it up so much here, but I’d be typing all day and would reach the word limit before I could finish.

That said, I definitely reccomend Blue Shift, especially to HL fans. It has a good story that actually expands on the story and lore of the original HL, as well as having some pretty cool connections to HL2, almost like Valve were trying to call back to this game when including Barney as a character. It also has a bit better focused weapon sandbox than HL1, and level design that is, for the most part, as good, if not better in some areas, like Xen for instance, than even the original game.

Playing through the OG Half-Life and expansions, I feel like Goldilocks. The base game is too long, too much save-scumming bad platforming segments, cheap enemy spawns, Opposing Forces is a sweet middle spot with a short but sweet campaign that gives you what the OG had to offer but with less BS and less focus on the obnoxious platforming, then there's Blue Shift... this would be the "too cold" porridge, the "too soft" bed.

The other reviews really aren't lying when they say that this game is balls short. I feel like the other reviews didn't emphasize how insanely easy this one is though. I played the OG Half-Life on hard, which is what I normally do with other games (unless a game has like, 5 difficulty modes and the hardest one is named something like "Legendary Nightmare Cancer", then I'll do the second highest), but in OG Half-Life, with the enemy spawns right behind you constantly and non-stop insta-death platforming, I had my a*s split like that time I spent the night at Bill Cosby's. So, I played through Opposing Forces on Normal and had a nice enough time. I did the same on Blue Shift and was practically falling asleep. I just use my strongest weapon and run out like Leeroy Jenkins in every encounter, then I'm rewarded with more med-packs than I've ever seen in any game ever. No lie, they give you about 20 for every 1/2 you need.

Then there's some obnoxiously slow segments, like when you're escorting one scientist past 8 areas you've already cleared out, and he stops every 2 inches to complain about his asthma or the heat. Dammit, Rosenberg. Then there's a crawling maze section on an alien planet that take's up about 20% of the total playthrough. 

Man. If I didn't practically get this game for $.20 in a pack along with the rest of the Half-Life series, I'd feel ripped off. If this game wasn't so short, I wouldn't have finished it. Word to the wise: Play through the OG Half-Life on normal ONLY if you really care about the backstory of Black Mesa and Freeman, play through Opposing Forces only if you want to see what the OG gameplay was like and want a nice enough time, skip to Half-Life 2 if you don't care about any of that, and do NOT waste your time with this one.

Half-Life: Blue Shift is an expansion pack for Half-Life that was released in 2001 and was developed by Gearbox Software, initially for the ill-fated Dreamcast port of the aforementioned game. In this expansion, you are not in the shoes of Gordon Freeman, but instead you're controlling Barney Calhoun, a security guard at the Black Mesa Research Facility that would later appear as a major NPC in Half-Life 2. He prepares to head off for his usual task when suddenly the resonance cascade from the original game occurs, and the elevator that he was in crashes. He wakes up a little later, now with the goal of trying to escape the facility with as many scientists as he can take with him (spoilers: only three.)
The gameplay isn't too different from the game it's based off of, with the most major difference being the view arms and the smaller selection of weapons to use. The combat is pretty good for its era, and there's quite a bit of puzzles to solve, and they're usually not too obtuse to the extent that you need to extensively rely on a walkthrough. I used one a few times, but that's largely due to my own fault more than anything.
With that said, the game can be frustrating at times due to the more limited amount of health resupplies compared to the original, not helped by the fact that Barney is unable to use the HEV charge stations to gain armor point-thingies. The AI hasn't aged all that well and that's can be very obvious with some of the friendly characters. 
The game is also very short compared to the original game and Opposing Force, which is a review for another time, and whether this is good or bad depends on your point of view. I played the game on easy, and even with several deaths, it only took my about two hours to beat.
For those who care more for story, this expansion provides the least amount of it compared to Opposing Force, let alone the original game. Again, whether or not this is a good thing is subjective. The only bearing it has on later entries in the Half-Life series is the fact that, as mentioned before, Barney returns as an NPC in Half-Life 2 and the episodes.
Overall, I give this game a 7/10. If you liked the first Half-Life, well, here's more of it.

[h1] Half-Life: Blue Shift [/h1]

Half-Life: Blue Shift é um pacote de expansão do jogo de ficção científica da Valve Corporation, Half-Life. O jogo foi desenvolvido pela Gearbox Software com a Valve e publicada pela Sierra Entertainment em 12 de junho de 2001. Blue Shift é a segunda expansão de Half-Life, pretendido ser parte de uma versão de Dreamcast do jogo original. Apesar desta versão ter sido cancelada, a versão para PC continuou em desenvolvimento como um produto separado. Foi lançado no Steam em 24 de agosto de 2005.

[h1] História [/h1]

[spoiler] Em Agosto de 2005 a Valve anunciou o lançamento oficial de Blue-Shift no Steam, possibilitando que usuários possam registrar seus números de série para adquirir um pacote de jogos. Half-Life: Blue Shift não teria sido implantado no sistema desde o início pois o jogo usa um motor diferente do Half-Life original. Ao contrário de Opposing Force, Blue Shift não oferece nenhum modo multiplayer, e também é uma expansão independente, não necessitando de Half-Life.
Nele, o jogador assume o controle de um segurança da Black Mesa, Barney Calhoun. Os inimigos são os mesmos de Half-Life, porém a expansão conta com algumas armas diferentes. O jogo também tem uma duração menor que o original. Barney passa por diversos pontos que interligam Half-Life e suas expansões, como o momento em que Gordon pula em um portal para entrar no planeta Xen, ou as diversas misteriosas aparições de G-Man. [/spoiler]
